I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the implementation of the ongoing small-scale technical assistance (TA) to the 
Government of People's Republic of China (PRC) on capacity development and financing of the 
first integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) power plant,1 some critical capacity, policy, 
and strategic analysis gaps were noted that could delay moving forward on carbon dioxide 
capture and storage (CCS) opportunities. The capacity development TA2 was conceptualized 
with the Department of Climate Change, National Development and Reform Commission (CC-
NDRC) and the Ministry of Finance during a Reconnaissance Mission in November 2008. 
During  the  Country  Programming  Mission  in  December  2008,  the  Government  formally 
requested the inclusion of the TA in the 2009 country program. The TA design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC is the world’s second-largest energy consumer after the United States and has 
the fastest growing energy sector in the world in terms of both consumption and generation. In 
2007, the PRC generated 3,256 terawatt-hours of electricity. Almost 83% of the total came from 
burning coal; 15% from hydropower; and 2% from nuclear, wind, and other alternative sources. 
Electricity generation consumed more than 55% of the 2.53 billion tons of coal produced in 2007. 
The Government has prioritized diversifying the energy mix to include more renewable, nuclear, 
and other alternative sources. However, coal will remain the dominant source of electricity 
production until at least 2030. Globally, electricity generation accounts for almost 30% of carbon 
dioxide (CO ) emissions. CCS is an integral part of all strategies to reduce greenhouse gas 
2  
emissions proposed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and the International 
Energy Agency (IEA).  
 
3.  The Government’s 11th Five-Year Plan, 2006–2010 aims to achieve a resource-effective 
and environment-friendly harmonious society, and targets a 20% reduction in energy intensity. 
Advanced coal-based electricity generation with higher efficiency on a par with international best 
practices  has  already  led  to  many  supercritical  and  ultra-supercritical  (USC)  plants  in  the 
country’s new generation stock.3 The feasibility of a 250-megawatt IGCC power plant at Tianjin 
is  being  considered. 4  This  plant  is  expected  to  be  operational  by  2010.  The  likely 
implementation of an IGCC plant provides the enabling power plant technology to contemplate 
cost-competitive precombustion CCS options, while the widespread use of USC plants does the 
same for post-combustion CCS options.5  
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People's Republic of China for Capacity Strengthening in Planning and 
Implementation of Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle Plant. Manila (TA 7146-PRC, approved on 8 October, 
for $200,000). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 23 January 2009. 
3  The supercritical and USC plants refer to the above critical points of water (374 degrees celsius [C] and 
22.15 megapascals  [MPa]).  The  supercritical  plants  typically  operate  in  the  400–500oC  range  with  thermal 
efficiencies of around 40%; and latest USC plants operate at 600oC and 30 MPa with thermal efficiencies of more 
than 46%. These above critical efficiencies are significantly higher compared to mid-thirties efficiencies from 
subcritical plants. Every 1% efficiency gain typically corresponds to about 2.5 million ton of avoided CO  emissions 
2
over the 30 years life of the plant.  
4  IGCC is a technology that turns coal into gas—synthetic gas (syngas), which is used to power a gas turbine whose 
waste heat is passed to a steam turbine system (combined cycle gas turbine). The impurities from the syngas, 
including CO , can be removed/captured before its combustion, which allows low-cost capture in a CCS project.     
2
5  The CCS application on high-efficiency coal-fired power plants such as IGCC and USC allows the capture and 
permanent storage of almost all of the CO  emissions, thus making them plants with near zero emissions.    
2

2   
 
4.  CCS is in its early stage of development internationally, and demonstration projects 
urgently need to be undertaken. There is no industrial-scale coal-based power plant with CCS.6 
IEA, in its Report to the (2008) G8 Summit7 in Hokkaido, Japan, recommended that at least 20 
fully integrated industrial-scale demonstration power plants with CCS be committed and new 
generation stock be prepared for future CCS retrofit. The full benefit of CCS cannot be achieved 
unless the CCS technology is demonstrated and deployed in major coal-based developing 
economies such as India and the PRC, where most of the new generation capacity will be 
added.  
 
5.  Recognizing the central role of coal in its energy security, the Government of the PRC 
launched the GreenGen Program in September 2005. The NDRC and the Ministry of Science 
and Technology support the program. The Greengen Co. Ltd (Greengen) was established in 
December 2005 with a mandate to lead the research, development, and demonstration of clean 
coal technologies; and to develop a near-zero emission, coal-based power plant in the PRC by 
2015.8 Greengen has identified a three-step technological development process to achieve this 
strategic  objective.  In  the  first  phase  (2006–2010),  a  250-megawatt  IGCC  plant  is  being 
designed and constructed at Tianjin.9  
  
6.  Technologically, the GreenGen Program is in sync with CCS development in developed 
countries. However, in the absence of any regulatory need and economic drivers,10 the PRC 
must balance its rapid growth agenda with investing in a promising but expensive, high-risk 
technology that may be crucial to its long-term energy security. Moreover, CCS projects will 
operate in a complex implementation structure,11 which will require pre-implementation work on 
an unprecedented scale with accompanying legal and regulatory issues and challenges. A 
comprehensive analysis of these issues is urgently needed, including providing a demonstration 
outlook, identifying gaps, providing capacity building in all aspects of the CCS chain, and 
developing a clear road map for CCS demonstration in the PRC.  
 
7.  Two complementary bilateral initiatives are being implemented in the PRC: (i) the United 
Kingdom–PRC Near-Zero Emission Coal Project, supported by the Government of the United 
Kingdom; and (ii) the European Commission-supported Cooperation Action within CCS China–
European Union Project. Both of these bilateral initiatives take long-term, phased approaches, 
focusing on knowledge sharing and capacity building up to 2010; and then identifying and 
preparing a CCS project for implementation by 2013. These ongoing interventions will provide 
useful and relevant analysis. However, moving from knowledge sharing to strategic analysis for 
formulating policies and preparing a demonstration project for investment will pose unique 
challenges that would be best served by a multilateral approach with clear understanding of 
regional issues, the policy environment, and the economic imperatives.12  
 
                                                 
6  The CCS community generally regards an industrial-scale power plant with CCS when at least 1 million tons of 
CO  annually is permanently stored in geological formations.   
2

http://www.g8.utoronto.ca/summit/2008hokkaido/2008-iea.pdf  
8  Greengen is a state-owned enterprise. Seven major energy enterprises in the PRC participate in the collaborative 
company, including all five major generators and the two largest coal producers. China Huaneng Group is the 
managing partner with a 52% equity stake.   
9 Tianjin IGCC project is included in the Country Programming Mission for the People's Republic of China (2009–
2011) for ADB financing. 
10 Because of its low per capita greenhouse gas emissions, the PRC has no mandatory emission reduction targets; 
CCS is not recognized as an eligible technology under the Clean Development Mechanism.   
11 The CCS project will extend beyond a traditional power plant boundary and to possible oil and/or gas fields or coal 
mines.  
12 Multilateral development banks are perceived as neutral and honest facilitators for technology transfer approaches 
and policy analysis, which are crucial elements for in the deployment of CCS technologies in developing countries.

3
8.  The Government supports the timely input from the TA to complement the ongoing and 
planned efforts of other development partners and to assist in the comprehensive analysis of 
key issues—institutional, legal, regulatory, policy, and concessional financing—that will help the 
decision and policy makers in considering a strategic approach to CCS demonstration in the 
short-term  and  its  future  deployment.  Early  preparation  of  a  forward-looking,  low-carbon 
technology and its likely demonstration will keep the GreenGen Program on target.  
 
9.  The TA is a logical extension of the ongoing support of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to the first IGCC demonstration power plant in the PRC. It is directly relevant to the 
country partnership strategy (CPS), 2008–2010.13 The proposed TA will directly address the 
resource efficiency and environmental sustainability pillar of the CPS by developing in-country 
capacity in an emerging near-zero emission technology for the coal-dependent energy sector. 
Clean coal technology development is one of the priority areas of the energy sector intervention 
in the CPS.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the TA will be the formulation of a draft strategy for CCS deployment in 
the  PRC.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  greater  capacity  to  plan  and  manage  the  CCS 
demonstration project. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The key outputs of the TA include (i) a comprehensive road map for CCS demonstration 
projects;  (ii)  essential  enabling  policies,  and  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks,  for  CCS 
demonstration; (iii) identification of priority demonstration projects and associated financing 
needs; and (iv) capacity assessment and comprehensive capacity development in critical areas 
of CCS demonstration.  
 
12.  The main activities of the TA will be to  
(i)  take stock of all relevant international efforts and their relevance to the PRC;  
(ii)  identify strategic choices and their cost–benefit comparisons on the complete 
CCS cycle—capture technologies (precombustion and/or post-combustion), CO  
2
chain—utilization, and storage;  
(iii)  analyze  and  recommend  a  potential  road  map  for  CCS  demonstration,  and 
identify key barriers;  
(iv)  evaluate international legal and regulatory frameworks (European Union directive, 
London Protocol, Australian legislation, and others) and their relevance to the 
PRC;  
(v)  identify capacity gaps and recommend a capacity strengthening plan, targeting 
policy and decision-making institutions and government agencies;  
(vi)  identify potential priority technologies and sites for demonstration projects, and 
undertake further research and preliminary prefeasibility assessment;  
(vii)  identify cost gaps and examine the availability of concessional funding, such as 
Climate Investment Funds and their relevance;

13.  In the initial stages of TA implementation, a stakeholders network will be established. 
Throughout  TA  implementation,  close  coordination  will  be  maintained  with  the  Executing 
Agency (EA), Implementing Agency (IA), and the stakeholders network to ensure that the TA 
takes into account, among others, the previous studies, Government priorities, existing plans, 
and results of complementary projects, and avoids any repetition. The key assumptions and 
risks are in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). CCS is in the early stages of 
development, and the economic rationale and incentives in the PRC are uncertain. Thus, the 
major  risk  is  that  reaching  a  consensus  on  the  road  map  and  associated  policy 
recommendations  may  take  considerable  time  and  effort,  likely  extending  beyond  the  TA 
implementation  phase.  However,  the  TA  is  designed  and  will  be  implemented  in  close 
coordination with the apex national policy and decision-making agency, CC-NDRC, which is the 
EA. This will ensure that the TA outputs will provide critical input to the emerging national 
priorities and plans. To enhance the relevance of the TA outputs to national plans and policies, 
an innovative approach is warranted in selecting the right experts and policy analysts for the TA 
(paras. 16–17).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.55 million. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance the equivalent of $1.25 million, of which $1.00 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Climate Change Fund (CCF)14 and $250,000 by a grant from ADB's TA special 
fund-others. The Government will finance the remaining $300,000 of the total cost through in-
kind contributions, including office accommodation and support facilities,15 counterpart staff, and 
data and other information needed for the TA. The TA will finance some office equipment,16 
which will be procured by Greengen in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, 
as amended from time to time) and handed over to the CC-NDRC upon completion of the TA. 
Greengen will provide the counterpart in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and cofinancing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The CC-NDRC will be the EA for the TA. Greengen will be the IA responsible for day-to-
day implementation of TA activities, coordination with other key stakeholders, and logistical 
support to the consultants, among others. Greengen has created a project management office 
(PMO) in its head office in Beijing to provide management support for TA implementation.  
 
16.  About 75 person-months of consulting services will be required (10 person-months for 
international consultants and 65 person-months for national consultants). ADB will engage 
international and national consultants, according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants

(2007, as amended from time to time). Because of the emerging nature of the technology, as 
well as the limited information sharing commercially, very few (if any) international consulting 
firms have core expertise in CCS with a credible record across the whole CCS chain. Being the 
first of such CCS intervention, ADB will first seek expressions of interest (EOI) from consulting 
firms, which will be evaluated to check their qualification in terms of—consulting firms' expertise 
and proven experience in similar activities in the last 5 years and their ability to engage with 
appropriate research institutes and knowledge centers internationally and in the PRC to meet 
the requirements of expertise across the whole CCS chain (capture, transport and storage, and 
legal and regulatory issues). In case no qualified EOIs were received by due date, ADB will then 
seek  assistance  from  major  international  institutions  and  knowledge  centers—such  as  the 
Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum; Global CCS Institute, Australia; and IEA17—to identify 
and  engage  individual  international  and  national  experts  following  the  selection method  of 
individual consultants.  
 
17.  The international consultants will have expertise in (i) CCS strategy development; (ii) 
technical areas over the whole CCS chain, especially capture and storage; (iii) policy, legal, and 
regulatory issues; and (iv) financial modeling and analysis. The national consultants will have 
expertise similar to that of the international consultants, as well as in-depth knowledge and 
expertise in these areas in the PRC. The international CCS expert will be the team leader and 
the national CCS technical expert will be the co-team leader. Together, they will coordinate the 
activities of all consultants. The national consultants will also include a coordinator to support 
the co-team leader in administering and managing a large group of national consultants. The 
coordinator will strengthen support to the PMO and enhance coordination between stakeholders, 
the EA, the IA, and ADB throughout the TA implementation. The outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. The procurement and disposal of equipment (para. 15) during 
the TA implementation will be carried out in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines. 
The  disbursement  arrangement  under  the  TA  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.18 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over about 12 months beginning May 2009 and finishing on 
30 April 2010. The consultants will submit an inception report within 4 weeks, an interim report 
within 12 weeks, a midterm report within 25 weeks, a draft final report within 40 weeks, and the 
final report within 48 weeks of field mobilization. Information on implementation progress and TA 
outputs will be disseminated through regular workshops and seminars. The outcome of the TA 
will be subject to evaluation by ADB and the Government, in accordance with their respective 
evaluation policies and requirements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for the Carbon Dioxide Capture and Storage 
Demonstration—Strategic Analysis and Capacity Strengthening, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) will be implemented under overall 
supervision and oversight by the Department of Climate Change, National Development and 
Reforms  Commission  and  day-to-day  coordination  and  guidance  by  Greengen  Co.  Ltd. 
(Greengen). TA implementation will be closely coordinated with relevant stakeholders, including 
the Ministry of Science and Technology, Academy of Science, relevant research institutes, and 
other well-known international and national knowledge centers, especially in firming up the TA 
outputs. The team of international consultants (10 person-months) will coordinate their work with 
the national consultants (65 person-months). The international consultants will have expertise in 
(i) carbon dioxide capture and storage (CCS) strategy development; (ii) technical areas over the 
whole CCS chain, especially capture and storage; (iii) policy, legal, and regulatory issues; and 
(iv) financial modeling and analysis. The national consultants will have expertise similar to that 
of the international experts, as well as in-depth knowledge and expertise in these areas in the 
People's Republic of China (PRC). The international CCS expert will be the team leader, while a 
national CCS technical expert in capture technology will be the coleader. Together, they will 
coordinate the activities of the all the consultants. In addition, the national consultants will 
include  a  coordinator  with  extensive  experience  in  coordinating  and  managing  a  team  of 
consultants, and administering TA from the Asian Development Bank.      
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
2.  CCS  Expert  and  Team  Leader  (3.0  person-months).  The  team  leader  will  be 
responsible  for  pulling  together  outputs  from  other  international  and  national  experts  in  a 
coherent report covering all areas of the TA. The national consultants coordinator will assist the 
team  leader  in  these tasks  and in  ensuring coordination  among  national  and  international 
experts. The team leader will also undertake following tasks:  
(i)  Review and assess CCS developmental activities worldwide and the activities 
being carried out in the PRC under the ongoing programs, including but not 
limited  to  the  United  Kingdom–PRC  Near-Zero  Emission  Coal  Project  and 
Cooperation Action within CCS China–European Union Project. 
(ii)  Capture  and  map  out  these  national  and  international  activities  and  their 
relevance to the TA activities; establish an information and knowledge network 
with other CCS initiatives in the PRC. National experts will assist in quickly 
familiarizing the team leader with ongoing CCS activities in the PRC and in 
establishing a stakeholder network.   
(iii)  Review and summarize results of previous studies and initiatives; and capture 
lessons learned internationally in formulating policies, regulations, programs, and 
targeted initiatives to promote CCS activities. 
(iv)  In  conjunction  with  national  consultants,  critically  examine  the  strategic 
importance of CCS in the national energy mix and long-term energy security, 
especially comparing and contrasting with other supply-side options such as 
nuclear  power,  wind  power,  and  others.  Evaluate  the  impacts  of  the  CCS 
deployment on electricity pricing, society, environment, etc.  
(v)  Analyze  the  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  constraints  of  CCS 
development, its demonstration, and potential future deployment in the PRC.  
(vi)  In consultation with other national and international experts on the team, identify

(i)  Prepare  an  indicative  cost  structure  with  and  without  CCS  coal-fired

B.  National Consultants 
 
7.  A team of national consultants will supplement and support the international consultants 
with similar expertise. The national consultants team will comprise (i) one co-team leader and 
CCS technical expert—capture technologies (9 person-months), (ii) one CCS strategy analyst (7 
person-months), (iii) one CCS technical expert on capture technologies (8 person-months), (iv) 
two CCS technical experts—CO  storage (7 person-months each), (v) one energy economist 
2
and policy analyst (7 person-months), (vi) one specialist on technology policy issues—transfer 
of technology and intellectual property rights issue (5 person-months), (vii) one environment and 
climate change policy analyst (7 person-months), and (viii) one national consultants coordinator 
(8 person-months). The co-team leader will provide the planning and project management 
leadership for the national consultants. Together with the team leader from the international 
consultants, the co-team leader will be the focal point for interacting with key stakeholders and 
ensuring  the  quality  of  the  TA  output  reports.  All  national  consultants  will  have  extensive 
knowledge of CCS development issues in the PRC. They will assist the respective international 
consultants in quickly becoming familiar with their tasks by reviewing relevant reports, analytical 
data, policies, regulations, and current strategic thinking and challenges in CCS.  
 
8.  The  national  consultants'  terms  of  reference  will  be  similar  to  the  international 
consultants, and they will carry out similar tasks in coordination with relevant international 
consultants. In addition, the national CCS strategy analyst will work with the international team 
leader and coleader in examining the strategic importance of CCS in the national energy mix 
and long-term energy security, especially comparing and contrasting with other supply-side 
options such as nuclear power, wind power, and others; and evaluate the impacts of the CCS 
deployment  on  electricity  pricing,  society,  the  environment,  etc.  The  national  specialist  on 
technology policy will also work with the international team leader and coleader on identifying 
creative  policies  for  the  transfer  of  technology  and  intellectual  property  rights  issues.  The 
national environment and climate change policy analyst will assist the team leader and coleader 
on the national climate change action plan and in identifying the strategic fit of CCS into similar 
national plans and activities.    
 
9.  The national consultants coordinator will assist the project management office of the IA 
and the team leader and coleader in all TA management and administration tasks throughout 
the TA implementation period. The national consultants coordinator will ensure that the tasks of 
selected consultants can be coordinated and managed in a timely and cost-effective manner, 
enhancing TA implementation.
